method.description: A comprehensive 6-step behavior change framework that moves clients from awareness to lasting transformation. Built on motivational interviewing principles and habit science, the T.H.R.I.V.E. Method addresses the whole person â€” not just their diet or exercise routine.

steps.title: Talk Through the Vision
steps.description: Use motivational interviewing to understand the client's 'why.' Uncover their deepest health goals and the emotional drivers behind them.

steps.title: Habits Inventory
steps.description: Map current habits, routines, and lifestyle patterns. Identify keystone habits â€” the small ones that create cascading positive change.

steps.title: Redesign the Routine
steps.description: Replace harmful habits with sustainable alternatives using the habit loop framework. Stack new behaviors onto existing routines for maximum adherence.

steps.title: Implement with Support
steps.description: Launch the new plan with daily check-ins, accountability structures, and contingency plans for inevitable setbacks.

steps.title: Validate Progress
steps.description: Measure wins â€” both quantitative (weight, labs, energy) and qualitative (confidence, mood, identity shift). Celebrate milestones publicly.

steps.title: Evolve the Plan
steps.description: Periodically reassess and upgrade the plan as the client grows. What worked in month 1 may need adjusting by month 3. Health coaching is iterative.

examQuestions.question: What is motivational interviewing primarily used for in health coaching?
options: Understanding the client's 'why' and deepest health goals
examQuestions.explanation: Motivational interviewing is a client-centered communication technique used to understand the client's deepest motivations and overcome ambivalence about change.

examQuestions.question: What does the 'R' in the T.H.R.I.V.E. Methodâ„¢ stand for?
examQuestions.explanation: The 'R' stands for 'Redesign the Routine' â€” replacing harmful habits with sustainable alternatives using the habit loop framework.

examQuestions.question: What is a 'keystone habit'?
options: A small habit that creates cascading positive changes in other areas
A habit you were born with
A habit that requires a gym
examQuestions.explanation: A keystone habit is a small behavioral change that naturally triggers positive changes in other areas of life, creating a domino effect of improvement.

examQuestions.question: Why do 95% of diets fail according to behavior change research?
options: They focus on restriction instead of building sustainable habits and systems
examQuestions.explanation: Most diets fail because they rely on willpower and restriction rather than building sustainable habits and addressing the psychological and environmental factors that drive eating behavior.

examQuestions.question: In the T.H.R.I.V.E. Methodâ„¢, what does the 'Evolve' step involve?
options: Starting a new program from scratch
Periodically reassessing and upgrading the plan as the client grows
examQuestions.explanation: The 'Evolve' step involves periodically reassessing and upgrading the coaching plan because what works in month 1 may need adjusting by month 3 â€” health coaching is iterative.

faq.q: How is health coaching different from personal training?
